newsitem.title: CHINA: Machines outdo man in China's wheat fields.
newsitem.headline: Machines outdo man in China's wheat fields.

text.p: Machines have out-performed man in China's wheat fields for the first time in the country's history, the Economic Information Daily said on Wednesday.

More than 800,000 mechanical harvesters had reaped 12.9 million hectares (31.9 million acres) of wheat so far in 1996, accounting for 56 percent of the area planted and exceeding the amount harvested by hand for the first time, it said.
The newspaper said mechanisation had shortened harvest times, but gave no other details and did not say how many farm workers had been displaced.

China must feed about one-fifth of the world's population with just seven percent of its arable land. Agricultural officials are eager to boost mechanisation in the nation's fields, many of which are tiny plots farmed entirely by hand.
